newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea to send geneticist team to crash site.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea to send geneticist team to crash site.

text.p: A three-member geneticist team would leave for the Pacific island of Guam on Saturday to help intentify South Koreans who died in the crash of a Korean Air Lines (KAL) jumbo jet, a construction and transporation ministry official said.
"Three genetic experts will head for Guam at 8 pm (1100 GMT) today. They will cooperate with the U.S. investigation team for the indentity of recovered bodies," he said.
He said Construction Minister Lee Hwan-kyun arrived at the crash site in early morning on Saturday with photocopies of fingerprints of 172 passengers aboard the plane.
State radio said Lee handed the files to the U.S. National Transporation Safety Board (NTSB) probing the crash.
Korean Air Flight 801 carrying 254 people plummeted into a hillside on Guam on Wednesday. Only 27 people survived the crash.
Covered in bandages, 20 survivors have so far been airlifted to South Korea and doctors said none had life-threatening injuries.
But three Korean nationals who remained on Guam were critically ill.
In Guam, families of passengers and crew were shown photographs of unidentified bodies on Saturday.
Matt Furman, member of the NTSB, told the Korean relatives that the photographs would help the team indentify their loved ones.
None of the bodies has so far been indentified.
The U.S. team had recovered only about 100 bodies from the wreckage, most in poor condition.
